## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-10-31T15:27:18Z
## Message ID: 20231031-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-10-31T12:50Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-10-29T15:20Z are caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived at L1 on 2023-10-28, reaching a maximum speed of approximately 625 km/s at DSCOVR (see notifications 20231029-AL-001 and 20231029-AL-002). The solar wind speed at L1 is currently around 490 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-10-29T15:20:00-RBE-001.

## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux is above 1000 pfu starting at 2023-10-29T15:20Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a coronal hole high speed stream which arrived at L1 on 2023-10-28. The solar wind speed observed at L1 is currently around 580 km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-10-29T15:20:00-RBE-001.

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Parker Solar Probe, Solar Orbiter)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-10-27T12:54:16Z
## Message ID: 20231027-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

O-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-10-26T23:14Z.

Estimated speed: ~1024 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 52 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -90/39 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-10-26T23:14:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Parker Solar Probe and Solar Orbiter (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME may reach Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-28T09:58Z and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-28T10:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2023-10-26T23:14:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20231027_024200_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20231027_024200_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20231027_024200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20231027_024200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_PSP_timeline.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20231027_024200_2.0_ENLIL_CONE_SolO_timeline.gif


## Notes: 

This CME event (2023-10-26T23:14:00-CME-001) is associated with M1.4 flare with ID 2023-10-26T22:47:00-FLR-001 from an unnumbered Active Region (N20W90) which peaked at 2023-10-26T23:24Z.

ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 18, 2023 - October 24, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-10-25T21:59:27Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-10-18T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-10-24T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20231025-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were 15 C-type CMEs and one O-type CME (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the C-type CME first observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-10-18T06:12Z may give a glancing blow to NASA missions Near Earth around 2023-10-22T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum Kp index of 2-3 (below minor) (see notification 20231018-AL-001). The arrival of this CME was not detected at L1.

It was also estimated that the following CMEs would impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-10-18T06:12Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-19T15:00Z (minor impact) and OSIRIS-APEX at 2023-10-21T15:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231018-AL-001)
2023-10-19T15:36Z   Lucy at 2023-10-27T02:39Z and Mars at 2023-10-24T03:10Z (see notification 20231019-AL-001)
2023-10-22T02:16Z   Lucy at 2023-10-27T14:00Z (glancing blow)
2023-10-22T22:25Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-25T10:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231023-AL-001)
2023-10-24T17:53Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-26T18:29Z (see notifications 20231024-AL-001 and 20231025-AL-001)
2023-10-24T20:48Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-27T03:14Z (see notification 20231025-AL-002)

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period 2023-10-21T06:00Z-09:00Z. This enhancement of geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-10-20T07:30Z which may have been associated with the weak arrival of the C-type CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery at 2023-10-16T12:09Z during the previous reporting period. This arrival may have also been detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data around 2023-10-20T07:50Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-10-25T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-10-31T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at low levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently two numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13468 (currently located around S10W48) produced low level C-class flaring throughout the reporting period and may continue to exhibit flaring activity before rotating off the Earth-facing disk on or around 2023-10-29.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A small coronal hole currently centered around N10W40 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO) may reach geoeffective longitudes on or around 2023-10-27. A coronal hole currently centered around longitude E30 and extending from latitudes S10 to N40 may reach a geoeffective longitude towards the end of the reporting period on or around 2023-10-31.

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for October 11, 2023 - October 17, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-10-18T20:07:05Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-10-11T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-10-17T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20231018-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity varied between low and minor levels during this reporting period with 1 M-class flare and 7 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery at 2023-10-16T12:09Z may give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-10-19T15:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-4 (below minor) (see notification 20231017-AL-001). An ensemble simulation was performed for this CME with 32 members which estimated the CME to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-10-19T09:28Z and 2023-10-19T17:33Z (average arrival 2023-10-19T13:30Z) for 6% of simulations. The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 66% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-4 range (below minor). Full details of the modeled event are available here: https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-10-16_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA048/Detailed_results_20231016_120900_ncmes1_sims32_LAHAINA048.txt (see notification 20231017-AL-002).

It was also estimated that the following CMEs would impact non-Earth locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-10-11T23:36Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-13T04:52Z and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-12T17:37Z (see notification 20231012-AL-001)
2023-10-12T07:36Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-13T08:00Z (glancing blow)
2023-10-12T14:12Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-14T14:00Z (glancing blow) and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-13T22:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20231012-AL-002)

## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-10-18T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-10-24T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently three numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13464 (currently located at N04W42) exhibited C-class flaring throughout the reporting period and may continue to exhibit flaring activity before it rotates off the Earth-facing disk around 2023-10-22. Additional flaring activity may occur throughout the outlook period from an unnumbered region currently visible in SDO imagery around N25E60.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and below minor levels during the outlook period. A slight increase in geomagnetic activity may be observed around 2023-10-19 in association with the predicted arrival of a C-type CME first observed in STEREO A COR2 at 2023-10-16T12:09Z (see notifications 20231016-AL-002, 20231017-AL-001, and 20231017-AL-002) as previously summarized above. Additionally, a small coronal hole currently centered around N45W20 (as seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO) may reach geoeffective longitudes on or around 2023-10-22.

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2023-10-16T12:09:00-CME-001 (see previous notifications 20231016-AL-002 and 20231017-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 32 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A for an average arrival of 2023-10-19T09:41Z for 3% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-10-19T09:28Z and 2023-10-19T17:33Z (average arrival 2023-10-19T13:30Z) for 6% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 66% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-4 range (below minor).

## Notes:
This CME event (2023-10-16T12:09:00-CME-001) is also predicted to have an impact at OSIRIS at 2023-10-19T08:15Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-10-18T01:10Z, and Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-17T08:26Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notifications 20231016-AL-002 and 20231017-AL-001).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:

## Summary:

Solar activity varied from minor to moderate levels during this reporting period with 5 M-class flares and 3 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the following CME would impact non-Earth locations:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-10-03T12:48Z   Mars at 2023-10-08T21:37Z, Solar Orbiter at 2023-10-04T06:29Z and Lucy at 2023-10-12T00:00Z (glancing blow) 

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu starting at 2023-09-27T12:00Z and remained elevated through 2023-09-30 (see notifications 20230927-AL-001, 20230927-AL-002, and 20230929-AL-001). Towards the end of the reporting period, the > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux crossed the 1000 pfu threshold again at 2023-10-03T14:05Z (see notifications 20231003-AL-001 and 20231003-AL-002). These elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely associated with the arrival of O-type CMEs first seen during the previous reporting period on 2023-09-22 and the possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream at L1 on 2023-09-27.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-10-04T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date: 2023-10-10T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary between low and moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently nine numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13451 (currently located at N16E13) and Active Region 13452 (currently located at N11E10) produced a few M-class flares during the reporting period and may exhibit continued flaring activity. As seen in the available EUV imagery from SDO, there is currently at least one unnumbered Active Region visible near the eastern limb around latitude S10 and perhaps another around latitude N30 which may also exhibit flaring activity during the outlook period. Additionally, a large filament structure spanning from S10W10 to N40E40 (as seen in SDO EUV imagery) could lift off the Earth-facing disk producing an associated CME during the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between low and minor levels during the outlook period. A couple of coronal hole structures currently visible in SDO EUV imagery centered around S20E25 and S30E40 may develop further and become geoeffective towards the end of the outlook period.
